skills.name: Understand the different terms involved in sampling and data collection
Understand how to use the Peterson Capture-Recapture method of sampling
Evaluate different methods of data collection, identifying bias

explanations.A: Data is the information you would collect in the sample. Think about a technique of taking a sample where everyone is equally likely to be chosen.

explanations.C: Not quite. In stratified sampling the size of each group determines how many people from that group are selected. Think about a sampling method where everyone is equally likely to be selected.
explanations.D: Almost, we are taking a sample. What type of sample would give everyone an equal chance of being selected?

explanations.A: I think you've halved the number of females at the company. We want to have only 50 people in the sample, so we can't have more than 50. What proportion of the company are female?
explanations.B: I think you have halved the number of people in the sample, but to find a stratified sample, we need to have the same proportion of females in the sample as in the company. How could we work out the proportion of females in the company?
explanations.C: I think you may have guessed that we would want more females in the sample than males. Make sure to calculate the sample values. We need to have the exact same proportion of females in the sample as in the company. How could we work out the proportion of females in the company?
explanations.D: To find the number of females that should be included in the stratified sample, we find the proportion of females in the company (248 ÷ 400) and then we multiply that by our sample size (50) to get 31.
